newsitem.title: USA: Computer technology seen shaving exploration costs.
newsitem.headline: Computer technology seen shaving exploration costs.

text.p: Emerging computer technologies could shave exploration costs for oil and natural gas producers by as much as half in the coming years, industry executives and analysts said on Wednesday.

Three-dimensional seismic surveys, directional drilling and improvements in how companies manage information also should help the industry meet increasing oil and gas demand, the experts said as they presented a report on the impact of computer technology on the oil and gas industry.

The largest publicly held companies budget a total $70 billion a year exploring for oil and gas. "Of that $70 billion, half of it may be wasted that we can attack through information technology," said Robert Peebler, president of Landmark Graphics Corp, a Halliburton Co subsidiary.

Exploration and production companies worldwide spend a total $6 billion a year on computerized information technologies, or about $0.25 per barrel of oil equivalent produced, Cambridge Energy President Daniel Yergin said.
After declining early in the decade, spending on technologies like three-dimensional seismic surveys, directional drilling and computer-aided design by the majors has rebounded upward, he said.

Three-dimensional seismic surveys, a computer-intensive process for mapping possible onshore and offshore oil and gas fields, will be used to find 75 percent of the estimated 10 million barrels per day of new capacity additions from discovered fields between 1995 and 2000, the report said.
About one in three of the additional barrels will be tapped with directional drilling equipment using complex computer guidance systems by the turn of the century, the report said.
